text: the defeat of democrat martha coakley by
republican scott brown for the US Senate
seat in Massachusetts not only affects
Massachusetts it has huge ramifications
for the Obama administration's agenda
earlier I spoke to x political editor
dick Stevenson and I started by asking
him what did the Democrats do now dick
the loss by Democrat Martha Coakley to
Scott Brown in the senate race in
massachusetts has rocked both parties of
course in different ways let's talk
first about the democrats and what they
might be trying to do to recover from
this what can they do well I think there
are both short-term and long-term
answers to that question in the
short-term the immediate question they
face is whether or not they can go ahead
with President Obama's health care bill
and if they do whether it needs to be
scaled back that is a subject that will
be intensely debated on the hill and at
the White House for several days then
there's the question of political
strategy going ahead for the midterm
elections in November and really it's
probably not too early for people in the
White House to be thinking about how
Obama positions himself heading into
2012 in the wake of this on that ladder
score I think what you're going to see
is probably a president who strikes on
the one hand a much more populist tone
that seeks to co-opt and channel the
anger that was clearly being expressed
by voters in the Massachusetts race but
at the same time makes a nod to some of
the more conservative complaints that
this race brought into stark relief
particularly when it comes to the
country siskel condition and the need to
attack budget deficits and the national
debt already you're seeing the White
House taking action on both of those
scores even before the polls closed in
Massachusetts tickets so striking that
year saying this because certainly
President Obama rode into office on some
of those populist themes about the
Washington being mired in gridlock about
of transparency about the state of the
economy about health care how in such a
short time did the tables get turned
well for one thing the Democrats are in
charge now Obama got elected to the
degree that this was about
anti-incumbent mood out in the country
and that some of that carried over from
2008 the Democrats are the natural
targets here they're in power they are
the incumbent party and that voter anger
is being directed at them now rather
than at george bush and the republicans
so that is definitely part of it having
said that there is also i think clearly
a reaction to the way that obama and the
democrats have governed over the last
year conversely dick the republicans
although they expected they would win
how do they capitalize on this or what
does that what does it mean for how they
may handle their issues and differently
or does it well to some degree i think
that this victory in massachusetts by
scott brown validates the republican
strategy in congress over the last year
of opposing obama at every turn if their
goal here was to block democratic
legislation and try to persuade the
country that obama and the democrats had
overreached then the results in
massachusetts seem to suggest that they
anticipated the mood of the country
pretty accurately now going forward the
republicans i think are going to have
trouble continuing to run as just on the
platform of saying no to obama and the
democrats at some point they're going to
have to have a more positive
forward-looking agenda and i think
you're already seeing the house
republicans beginning to grapple with
that by putting together a kind of 2010
version of a contract with america
